t: Song of Solomon 5
The Beloved
I*pn have come to my garden, my sister, my*i spouse; I*ld have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I*ld have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I*ld have drunk my wine with my milk.
(To His Friends)
Eat,*pn O friends! Drink,*ld yes, drink deeply, O*ld beloved ones!
The Shulamite’s Troubled Evening
The Shulamite

I*pn sleep, but my heart is awake; It*ild is*i the voice of my beloved! He*ld knocks, saying,*i “Open*ld for me, my sister, my love, My*ld dove, my perfect one; For*ld my head is covered with dew, My*ld locks with the drops of the night.”
I*ld have taken off my robe; How*ld can I put it on again?*i I*ld have washed my feet; How*ld can I defile them?
My*ld beloved put his hand By*ld the latch of*i the*i door,*i And*ld my heart yearned for him.
I*ld arose to open for my beloved, And*ld my hands dripped with*i myrrh, My*ld fingers with liquid myrrh, On*ld the handles of the lock.

I*ln opened for my beloved, But*ld my beloved had turned away and*i was gone. My*ld heart leaped up when he spoke. I*ld sought him, but I could not find him; I*ld called him, but he gave me no answer.
The*ld watchmen who went about the city found me. They*ld struck me, they wounded me; The*ld keepers of the walls Took*ld my veil away from me.
I*ld charge you, O daughters of Jerusalem, If*ld you find my beloved, That*ld you tell him I am*i lovesick!
The Daughters of Jerusalem
What*pn is*i your beloved More*ld than another*i beloved, O*ld fairest among women? What*ld is*i your beloved More*ld than another*i beloved, That*ld you so charge us?
The Shulamite
My*pn beloved is*i white and ruddy, Chief*ld among ten thousand.
His*ld head is*i like*i the finest gold; His*ld locks are*i wavy, And*ild black as a raven.
His*ld eyes are*i like doves By*ld the rivers of waters, Washed*ld with milk, And*ild fitly set.
His*ld cheeks are*i like a bed of spices, Banks*ld of scented herbs. His*ld lips are*i lilies, Dripping*ld liquid myrrh.
His*ln hands are*i rods of gold Set*ld with beryl. His*ld body is*i carved ivory Inlaid*ld with*i sapphires.
His*ld legs are*i pillars of marble Set*ld on bases of fine gold. His*ld countenance is*i like Lebanon, Excellent*ld as the cedars.
His*ld mouth is*i most sweet, Yes,*ld he is*i altogether lovely. This*ld is*i my beloved, And*ld this is*i my friend, O*ld daughters of Jerusalem!
